question.name: 16.4.3 Properties of power series
question.questiontext:
Differentiation and integration of power series

It is worth keeping the in mind even if you have not seen differentiation and integration before. This is one of the more elegant aspects of power series but feel free to return here when later.

Let \(P_1\) and \(P_2\) represent two power series with radii of convergence \(R_1\) and \(R_2\) respectively. We can combine \(P_1\) and \(P_2\) together by addition. We find the following properties:

Key Point

If \(P_1\) and \(P_2\) are power series with respective distinct radii of convergence\(R_1\) and \(R_2\) then the sum \((P_1 +P_2)\) is a power series with the radius of convergence being the smaller of \(R_1\) and \(R_2\).


More care needs to be taken if the radii agree. In general we can only say that the radius of convergence of the sum of the series is at least the common radius of convergence of the two summands.

Power series can also be differentiated and integrated on a term by term basis:

Key Point

If \(P_1\) is a power series with radius of convergence \(R_1\) then \[ \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}x}(P_1) \quad \mathrm{and} \quad \int(P_1)\mathrm{d}x\] are each power series with radius of convergence \(R_1\)

Example

Using the known result that \[(1+x)^p = 1 + px + \dfrac{p(p-1)}{2!}x^2 + \cdots \qquad |x|<1,\] choose \(p=\dfrac{1}{2}\) and by differentiating obtain the power series expression for \((1+x)^{-\frac{1}{2}}.\)

Solution

\[(1+x)^{\frac{1}{2}} = 1 + \dfrac{x}{2} + \dfrac{\frac{1}{2}\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)}{2}x^2 + \dfrac{\frac{1}{2}\left(-\frac{1}{2}\right)\left(-\frac{3}{2}\right)}{3!}x^3 + \cdots\]

Differentiating both sides \[\dfrac{1}{2}(1+x)^{-\frac{1}{2}} = 1 - \dfrac{1}{2}x + \dfrac{(-\frac{1}{2})(-\frac{3}{1})}{2}x^2 + \cdots \] This result can, of course, be obtained directly from the expansion for \((1+x)^p\) with \(p=-\dfrac{1}{2}\).
